title.narrative: Protection of Women's Rights in BGD (BNWLA)
Protection of Women's Rights in BGD (BNWLA)

description.narrative:
The development problem that the intervention aims to address is that protection of women’s rights comes from the gender-based power structure in the family, society, and the state. Discrimination against women is very common in Bangladesh and affects the quality of their life. Among the many challenges with regard to women's rights in the country are issues of child marriage, the system of dowry, sexual harassment, and domestic violence. A culture of impunity exists in Bangladesh that denies justice to victims of human rights abuse in most cases. Thus, BNWLA has designed the new phase as a continuation of the previous one that was focused on providing legal aid support to female victims of human rights violation. The overall objective of the new phase is 'Women and girls in Bangladesh are less vulnerable to all forms of violence and better protected from the threat of such violence'. The expected outcomes of the intervention are 1) Government and service providers are accountable to women and girls for prevention, protection and response, 2) Women and girl survivors safely access adequate and appropriate support services (shelter, medical, psychosocial, security, income generation), and 3) Women and girls safely access justice at all levels including within customary and religious laws
The Embassy has experience of good cooperated with BNWLA from four previous phases of support, the first three of which were done jointly with other like-minded development partners.

Utvecklingsproblemet som insatsen syftar till att ta itu med är att brotten mor kvinnors rättigheter har sitt ursprung i könsmaktsstrukturer i familjen, samhället och staten. Diskriminering av kvinnor är mycket vanligt i Bangladesh och påverkar kvaliteten på deras liv. Bland de många utmaningar när det gäller kvinnors rättigheter i landet är frågor om barnäktenskap, systemet med hemgift, sexuella trakasserier, och våld i hemmet. En kultur av straffrihet råder i Bangladesh som i de flesta fall förnekar rättvisa för offren för brott mot de mänskliga rättigheterna. Just därför har BNWLA utformat den nya fasen som en fortsättning på den tidigare som var inriktad mot att ge rättshjälpsstöd till kvinnor som utsatts för kränkningar av sina mänskliga rättigheter.
Det övergripande målet för den nya insatsfasen är att kvinnor och flickor i Bangladesh är mindre sårbara för alla former av våld och bättre skyddade från hot om våld. De förväntade resultaten av interventionen är 1) regeringen och leverantörer av sociala tjänster är ansvariga inför kvinnor och flickor att förebygga, skydda och respondera, 2) överlevande kvinnor och flickor får tillgång till lämpliga och tillräckliga stödtjänster (skydd, medicinsk, psykosocial, säkerhet, inkomstgenerering ), och 3) kvinnor och flickor får tillgång till rättvisa på alla nivåer även inom traditionella och religiösa lagar.
Ambassaden har god erfarenhet av samarbetade med BNWLA från fyra tidigare faser av insatsstöd, varav de tre första gjordes tillsammans med andra likasinnade givare.
Women and girls in Bangladesh are less vulnerable to all forms of violence and better protected from the threat of such violence.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Protection of Women's Rights in Bangladesh(BNWLA)

description.narrative: To achieve the above-mentioned objectives PWR project worked under five components. The component of “basic awareness rising” was actively led by “Leaders of Influence” (LOI) pool in the community level. Trainings were provided to this pool to bring change in the mind-set, attitude and behavior of community people. In Legal Literacy Session the participants (at school & community level) started to learn about laws and policies relating to rights of women and girls. In the component “resolving individual problems through formal and informal justice system” training was provided to local level lawyers and law students. Unreported cases were identified instantly through Legal Aid Camps at union and upazila level. In working areas, paralegal groups were formed and orientated regarding their role and responsibilities for reducing violence against women and girls. Legal service delivery system was also provided in all working areas of the community for relief. Fact finding, shalish/mediation were also conducted effectively. In the component “improve administration of justice system”, two modules- one for “Improved Performance and Credibility of Prosecutorial System” (participants: Public Prosecutors, Additional Public Prosecutor, Assistant Public Prosecutors and Special Public Prosecutors) and another for “Court Administration, Gender and Equal Opportunities" (participants: court administrative staffs like-Peshkar, Nazir, Sherestadar) were prepared. Through these modules trainings and advocacy workshop were arranged to sensitize and improve administration of justice system. In the component “strengthening oversight & enforcement mechanism” an assessment on justice system was conducted to figure out the existing causes and consequences of corruption.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
